awd_titl_txt: Mitonuclear Interaction and the Genetic Architecture of Phenotypic Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will evaluate how mitochondrial dysfunction and mitochondrial-nuclear interaction contribute to evolution across three levels of biological organization - molecular-genetic, cellular, and organismal. The PIs will study evolutionary process within the context of the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC). Evolution experiments using ETC-deficient Caenorhabditis elegans nematodes will be combined with whole-genome sequencing, bioinformatics and mitochondrial phenotyping to study the genetic bases of maladaptive and compensatory adaptive evolution - the process whereby natural selection favors changes at loci that compensate for the deleterious effects of a mutant allele. The ETC is crucial for eukaryotic life and its proper functioning relies on the maintenance of favorable mitonuclear interactions; it is thus ideal for studying the patterns and functional bases of both forms of evolution and the role of mutation in shaping mitonuclear genome integration. Further, ETC dysfunction is a proposed cause of variation in genome-wide spontaneous mutation rates. This work will reveal the effects of different forms of ETC damage on nuclear and mitochondrial genome stability and concomitant changes in mitochondrial function and organismal fitness. Because few studies have addressed the population-level consequences of compensatory mutation or the genetic mechanisms of compensatory evolution in eukaryotic systems, and because mitochondrial metabolism and ETC function are highly evolutionarily conserved, findings are expected to be of broad interest and relevant to other eukaryotes.

Broader Impacts. The project will train students in cutting-edge genomics research, provide important data and resources to the scientific community, and expand both PIs' educational and outreach activities. Minority and other students with gain meaningful research and science education experience. The PIs will co-train graduate and undergraduate students, participate in science outreach to minority student groups and a local Native American high school, and develop bioinformatics learning modules based on the research to be taught in their respective undergraduate Genetics courses at Portland State University and Oregon State University.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal evaluated how mitochondrial dysfunction and mitochondrial-nuclear genome interaction contribute to evolution across three levels of biological organization—molecular genetic, cellular, and organismal. The PIs studied evolutionary process within the context of the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC)—a molecular system whose proper functioning is essential for nearly all eukaryotic life. Laboratory evolution experiments using ETC-deficient Caenorhabditis elegans nematodes were combined with whole-genome sequencing, bioinformatics and mitochondrial phenotyping to study the genetic bases of maladaptive and compensatory adaptive evolution—the process whereby natural selection favors changes at genetic loci that compensate for the deleterious effects of a mutant allele. ETC functioning relies on the maintenance of favorable mitonuclear epistatic interactions; this system was thus ideal for studying the patterns and functional bases of both forms of evolution and the role of mutation in shaping mitonuclear genome integration. Further, ETC dysfunction is a proposed cause of variation in genome-wide spontaneous mutation rates. This work revealed the effects of ETC damage on nuclear and mitochondrial genome stability and concomitant changes in mitochondrial function and organismal fitness. The specific aims were to: 1) Identify and characterize the mutations responsible for maladaptive evolution in ETC-deficient populations, and 2) Characterize the patterns and identify the mutations responsible for compensatory evolution in such populations. We achieved both aims and are taking advantage of opportunities presented by interesting, unanticipated results for future work.

Intellectual Merit: These research activities improved our knowledge about the how mitochondrial ETC damage affects spontaneous mutational processes, fitness and physiological decline, and revealed the relative contributions of mitochondrial versus nuclear genomes to the compensatory evolution of ETC dysfunction and the degree to which compensatory adaptation is aided by mitonuclear interaction. Results of Aim 1 indicate that, even under conditions of extreme genetic drift, populations can maintain or slightly improve their fitness through selective elimination of deleterious mutations and fixation of novel beneficial mutations. In other words, mutation-driven adaptive evolution is surprisingly powerful even under unfavourable population genetic conditions. Results of Aim 2 provide convincing evidence for adaptation via mitonuclear epistasis, and provide some of the first direct evidence that mitochondrial DNA can be an important contributor to such evolution. Because few studies have addressed the population-level consequences of compensatory mutation or the genetic mechanisms of compensatory evolution in eukaryotic systems, and because mitochondrial metabolism and ETC function are highly evolutionarily conserved, findings are expected to be of broad interest and relevant to other eukaryotes.

Broader Impacts: This project facilitated training of 3 MS (1 female) and 1 PhD (female) students. The project also provided meaningful research experiences for 1 high school student and 7 undergraduates (5 female; 5 minority). The minority students were members of the NSF-funded PSU Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Program. Other broad impacts include multiple presentations by the PIs and trainees on the funded research, and topics such as Building Science Capital, to student groups including: LSAMP conference participants, PSU Ronald E. McNair and NIH BUILD EXITO Scholars, and introductory Biology courses. The PIs’ work on projects to increase STEM retention and graduation rates of minorities lead to a recently-funded NSF S-STEM award. Finally, mutations in human orthologs of the studied ETC genes are causal in metabolic diseases; findings will have practical implications for human health.
